title: How is accuracy increased by decreasing the limit of precision? - Quora

response.answer_text: Accuracy is never increased by decreasing precision. Diminished precision results in haphazard results. The key to accuracy is precision. When I’m loading ammunition specifically for precision shooting, I want each and every case to be as precisely uniform as possible. Case length, the size of the priming hole, the amount of case mouth chamfering, and when I can, even the weight of every case. I want my primers seated to as uniform a depth in the pocket as possible, which is why I never prime cases on the loading press. I want each and every bullet to be as uniform in weight, not varying more than 1/10th of one grain (there are 7,000 grains in a pound; 437.5 gr. per ounce, just to give you an idea of how minute and precise powder charges are weighed or measured). I want every single bullet to be seated to the exact same depth, with a variation of no more that .0001″. Likewise, the firearm itself must be built with a high degree of precision in order to produce sterling accuracy. A 1894 Winchester lever action will never give you the level of accuracy you can get from a pre-1964 Winchester Model 70 bolt gun that has had a Timney trigger installed and a well-fitted glass bedded bull barrel fitted to the stock. The reason for this? Precision. A gun that rattles when you shake it won’t produce the same results as a finely tuned rifle that has received the kind ministrations of an experienced gunsmith.
